posts.cooked:
My team got the new VH-109 radio at worlds and we‚Äôve been having some issues with it. At first, connecting wirelessly was a little confusing but we got that to work eventually.

Now we have this very odd new problem which I believe is due to the radio but I could be wrong. Our CAN bus randomly went out and all CAN devices started blinking red. We disconnected the CAN loop and reconnected it which worked once but then it went back to red after another power cycle. We then tried to switch out the radio back to the open mesh radio and that seemed to have fixed our CAN issue. We are wiring the VH-109 through POE and the same is true for the open mesh radio.

posts.cooked:
Unfortunately I don‚Äôt see how the radio would be connected to a CAN problem.

Can you post details of your CAN setup?

posts.cooked:
The radio is powered through the RIO port on the radio using a radio power module. The only other device connected to the radio is a rpi4 which is connected to a camera and powered through a voltage converter.

The CAN wiring is connected as it has been throughout the entire season, the first device of the loop is a falcon 500 and it ends with a falcon 500. All CAN wires are yellow to yellow and green to green. All of the motors and sensors we have are CTRE . Besides the 13 falcon 500‚Äôs we have 4 CANcoders and one pigeon 2.0.
We are going to try powering the radio through DC input and see if that makes a difference.

posts.name: Gavin Matthews
posts.cooked:
How is the RPM powered?

As a diagnostic procedure, consider (with power off) disconnecting both the roboRIO and PDP / PDH from the CAN bus and then checking the end-to-end resistance for yellow and for green lines.

posts.name: Domtech
posts.cooked:
MilkMan:

Now we have this very odd new problem which I believe is due to the radio but I could be wrong. Our CAN bus randomly went out and all CAN devices started blinking red.

Almost certainly an issue with the CAN loop, not the radio.

MilkMan:

the first device of the loop is a falcon 500 and it ends with a falcon 500.

Normal the first device is either the RIO or a CANivore, which one are you using? I‚Äôm assuming RIO since you didn‚Äôt say. Normally the last device is your power distibution board or a terminating resistor. How are you terminating the loop?

MilkMan:

All of the motors and sensors we have are CTRE . Besides the 13 falcon 500‚Äôs we have 4 CANcoders and one pigeon 2.0.

That is a lot of CTRE device to have on the slower RIO bus, what is you CAN utilization like?

posts.name: Nathan Zhou
posts.cooked:
Is your CAN bus terminated at BOTH end with a 120 Ohm resistor?

On one end of your CAN bus, it‚Äôs typically roboRIO or CANivore. If roboRIO is the case, it includes a termination resistor (so no worry). If you‚Äôre using CANivore, you needs to make sure it‚Äôs internal terminaltion is turned on by following this article .

Now look at the the end of your CAN loop. If it‚Äôs originated from roboRIO and end at PDP or PDH , follow this guide to enable the termination resistor on PDH or PDP by setting a switch or jumper to ON potision. If these two are NOT your last device, than you need to manually add a 120 Ohm resistor to the last device. If it‚Äôs originated from CANivore, than you definitely would be needing a termination resistor at the end.

Not having a termination resistor does not mean your CAN bus would completely not work but from ‚Äúweird thing could occor‚Äù to ‚Äúcompletely not working‚Äù, anything could happen, especially the longer cable you run on CAN bus.

If you‚Äôre unsure about the termination on the OTHER end, here‚Äôs a way to test things out.

Have robot powered off

Unplug CAN bus from roboRIO or CANivore

Use a digital multimetr to measure the RESISTANCE between the two green and yellow CAN wire

If the reading is around 120 to 60 ish Ohm, it‚Äôs wired properly. If it‚Äôs near 0 Ohm, it‚Äôs shorted somethere. If it‚Äôs serval kilo Ohm, it‚Äôs not terminated properly at the other end.

Also as @Domtech mentioned, check your CAN utilization rate on Driver Station. If it‚Äôs nearly 90% and those motors are connected on roboRIO bus, better get a CANivore or upgrade your Phoenix .
